titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Began this morning to read the third volume of Buchholz’s History of the Electorate of Brandenburg. My patience in reading this book has held out beyond my expectations.— The two first volumes, which I have now read, only bring down the History to the year 1457 When the sovereignty was established in the present reigning house— The preceding period is very obscure and the Events dubious.— The knowledge of such History can be of very little use.— Spent the Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Casino, with Mlle: de Marwitz, Miss Hagen and Count Lottum.— Did not stay to supper.

2. Called upon the Queen’s Grande Maitresse, Madame de Voss, to enquire after the health of the king and queen; both of whom are unwell— The subscription party was at Count Zinzendorff’s, and extremely numerous. Played whist with Madame de Wulknitz, Madam de Grappendorf, and a Countess Blumenthal.— After supper, there was a Ball, at Mr: Dorville’s, in the same house— But we did not stay to supper.

3. We had this Evening a party, nearly the same as at Lord Talbot’s some days ago.— About forty persons—a very small party in this Country— We danced till about four in the morning.— Count Bruhl and Dr: Brown, & Count Golofkin, and their families— The English Gentlemen now in town,— Countess Panin— M. and Mad: Bacounin, and several of Mrs: A’s acquaintance among the young Ladies of this Country. About supper time Prince Radziwill and Mr: de Sartoris came in. Danced almost the whole time myself.

4. Dined at the Duchess of Holstein Beck’s, or Princess Baratinsky’s.— She lives in the same house where the Swedish Minister Baron Schultz lived, and died— She has furnished it very superbly, and has a number of very fine pictures.— A frenchman by the name of La Fontaine lives with her, to whom she is said to be privately married.— She entertains a great deal of company, and gives one or two great dinners every week, to about thirty persons.— Sat by Mr: Bacounin and Mr: Sievers at table.— Called in the afternoon to see Prince Augustus, and Mr: Arbuthnot, but could see neither of them— Remainder of the evening at Dr: Brown’s. Chess with Miss Bishopswerder and with Dr: Brown.

5. Mrs: Adams very ill with a cold. Wrote to Pitcairn and to Mr: Murray. Evening at the party and supper of Mr: Massow, for Mr: Engeström. Reversi with Countess Brühl, Countess de Stein, and the eldest Miss Blumenthal— Did not stay to supper.

6. Visit to Mrs: A. this morning from Mr: and Mrs Errington—after dinner from Miss Estoff and Miss Kell—from Lord Talbot and Count St: George— A couple of hours in the Evening at the Casino. Afterwards at Dr: Brown’s and supped. Played with the Doctor at Chess.
7. Short walk before dinner— Mrs: A. continues unwell— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Played Reversi with Madame de Hagen, Madame de Reede and the Baron de Stein.

8. The Miss Brühls, and Miss Brown’s passed the Evening with Mrs: A— Visit likewise from Miss Dorville.— I suspend for the present my reading of Buchholz, which becomes too tedious and take Lessing in his stead.

9. Dined at Count Schulenburg’s with a company of about 25 persons.— Visit from Madame de Bacounin, and from Mr: Washington.— Story of the Princess Louis— Evening party at the Vicount d’Anadia’s—played chess with M. de Bacounin— Came and supped at Dr: Brown’s. Found Mr Livingston and Mr: Arbuthnot there.

10. Reading Lessing’s Laocoon, which is ingenious and amusing.— Count and Countess Bruhl, and their eldest daughter spent the Evening with us.— Mr: Livingston and Mr: Arbuthnot here a couple of hours.— Played chess with Count Bruhl.

11. Visit in the afternoon to Countess Golofkin— Evening party at the Landgrave’s— Company large. Played Reversi with Madame de Hagen, Miss Bishopswerder and Count Goltz.— Out of humour very improperly; only because I was cheated.
12. Weather cold again— Party this Evening at Count Podewils’s (not the Marshall)— Played Whist with Madame de Saldern, M. d’Aguilar, and MrLatter part of the Evening and supper at Dr: Brown’s.

13. The Carnaval usually commences here on the 6th: of January, or twelfth day. It has this year been postponed a week on account of the king’s state of health, and commences therefore this day.— But the queen held no Court—perhaps on account of the Princess Louis’s adventure.— She left town for Anspach at 5 in the morning of the 11th:— Mr: and Mrs: Errington spent the Evening with us.

14. The first Opera was performed— (Atalanta.) There are two to be acted, each of them four times, during the carnaval. The performances are to be on Monday’s and Friday’s, and are all entirely at the king’s expense.— There are boxes appropriated to various persons of distinction—one for the Cabinet, and foreign Ministers.— But the queen holds a sort of Court in her own box, at which the foreign Ministers make their appearance in the course of the Evening.— The strangers who have been presented at Court, are likewise in the queen’s box, which fronts the stage, and is very large.— The Music was very good— The scenery beautiful, but with only two changes— The dancing not remarkable. The house very handsome, but poorly lighted. No applause is permitted.— Mrs: A. took Mrs: Errington with her.— The performance began at about half past five, and finished a little before nine.

15. Walking out this forenoon I met Dr: Brown, who told me of the Death of Prince Frederic of Orange.— This Event however is not to suspend the amusements of the Carnaval— This Evening was a Ridotto at the Opera house, which the king and queen both attended.— We did not go.— Spent most of the Evening with Mr: and Mrs: Errington at the Hotel de Russie— She plays on the Piano forte and sings very well.
16. Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s. The Prince himself unwell with a cold, and did not make his appearance. Played Reversi with Countess Brühl, Madame de Marwitz and the Baron de Thülemeyer.

17. Court, held this Evening by the Queen mother for the first time, since she has been out of mourning.— The Ladies in full dresses and hoops.— Came home early and passed the remainder of the Evening and supped at Mr: Schickler’s— Had music there— Company of 40 persons.— The Duke of Brunswic at the Court.

18. Dined with the English Prince Augustus, at Lord Elgin’s house— The queen of England’s birth day.— Met there Mr: de Luc, the chemist and theologian.— Sat late at table— Many toasts and songs.— At the Opera about half an hour in the Evening.— The same as on Monday, with one new Scene.— Came home before it was finished.

19. Wrote very busily— Read after dinner the 6th: book of Paradise Lost, in which there appeared to me to be many things open to criticism— Evening, for an hour at Marshall Möllendorf’s Assembly.— Afterwards at Dr: Brown’s where I found considerable company.— With the Doctor in his library which is excellent. He shewed me the Virgil with a translation in greek verse, lately published in Russia.

20. The queen held a splendid Court— The Ladies all in large hoops— Mrs: A. did not go.— It was held at the apartments in the royal palace.— Played Whist, with Madame de Saldern, Count Lendorf and Mr:The king asked me how I liked the Opera— Whether I understood Italian &c &c.— Read this afternoon the
7th: book of Milton’s Paradise lost— In the morning I have finished Lessing’s Laocoon, and am now reading the posthumous fragments annexed to that work, which is itself a fragment.

21. Translated a fable of Gellert.— The Painter.— The same which the author repeated to Frederic 2. at the interview which he had with him at Leipzig— These exercises are an employment of time as valuable, and even more valuable than playing cards at tea parties, or hearing an Opera— I allow for them very few moments but what would otherwise be thus applied.— This day it delayed my attendance at the Opera untill 7 O’clock— It was again the same that we had before.— Was presented there to the Duke of Brunswic.

22. Reading Lessings disquisition upon the question how the antients used to paint the figure of Death. Party in the Evening and Supper at Count Armin’s— The king, queen &c there— Played Whist with Madame de Reck— The Prince of Hesse Rhinfels, and Baron Hagen— After supper almost all the company went to the Redoute, or Maskerade, which was excessively dull.— We stayed there untill about 1: o’clock— The queen had retired a little earlier.

23. Mrs: Adams unwell all day, with an head ache I now spend my time in a kind of leisure, which may be called idleness— Mr: Richards called to see us.— The whole Evening at home— The first time these many days.

24. Mrs: A. was not well enough to go to the ball this Evening at the Queen mother’s.— Mrs: Errington pass’d the Evening with her— I went to the Ball— Played whist with Mr: Kökeritz, the king’s aid de camp. Mr Knoblauch, and Major Wardenberg.— Read the 8th: book of Paradise lost this afternoon.

25. Did not go to the Opera— Madame de Sartoris, Miss Estoff and Mrs: Errington pass’d the Evening with Mrs: Adams— Reading Denina’s essay upon the life and reign of Frederic 2. superficial, and poorly written.

26.— Finished the second volume of Lessing’s antiquarian writings, and began the third of his dramatic works I am not much pleased with them.— Evening at the Assembly, at Count Schulenburg’s— There were near four hundred persons there— Played Whist, with Madame de Saldern, the Baron de Hagen, and the Baron de Wurmser.— Mrs: A passed the Evening with Mrs: Errington.

27. Called upon the English Prince Augustus, but he was not at home— The queen gave him this Evening, a splendid ball, it being his birth day.— Played whist with Mlle: d’Otterstädt, Mr: Helbig & Mr: Sievers. During supper, I had some conversation with the king, who told me of a young man here, who had learnt the Chinese language— We came home between 12 and 1. o’clock— Mrs: Errington was presented at Court— Mr: Arbuthnot sent me this afternoon the posthumous works of Madame Necker. Received several Letters.

28. Read some of Madame Necker’s Observations.— Letters from America— At the Opera this Evening. It was much superior to the former though by the same author and composer— Its title Armida.— It has only three acting performers, but a much smaller proportion of dancing than the Atalanta.

29. This Evening at Count Arnim’s, at the party previous to the Redoute, similar to that of this day last week. But we did not stay to supper nor go to the Redoute.— Played Reversi with Madame de Stein, Mlle: Dorville and Mr: deRead after dinner the 10th. book of Paradise lost.

30. Finished the 21st: volume of Lessing’s works, containing plays.— His only Comedy of much worth is the last; Minna, von Barnhelm.— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s.— The company numerous— Played Whist with Countess Unruh, and two Gentlemen— Stayed to supper.

31. Began reading the 22d: vol: of Lessing, containing his theatrical fragments.— Evening at the ball given by the Queen mother.— Played Whist with Countess Moltke, Mlle: de Hagen, and a Gentleman of Mecklenburg.— Late home, though we did not stay to supper.

Day. The life of dissipation at all times in some measure indispensible here, is doubly so, during the carnaval— Rise at about eight— Read German a couple of hours— Breakfast;— read or write untill 2.— Walk— Dine between three and four— Read half an hour after dinner— Evening almost always in company— Generally at home before eleven.—
